text: Any elegant way of doing optional parameters in Julia? I know you can just use multiple dispatch but what if i have 10 optional parameters? What is the best julia practice then?

How about:
```function foo(some, required, variables;
        optional_variable_1=default_1,
        optional_variable_2=default_2,
        optional_variable_3=default_3,
        optional_variable_4=default_4
    )
    # Function body
    # do some things
end```

text:
I should have clarified what I mean by optional! I was refering to python-like optionality where you can do:
```def plot(X, output_file=None):
   ...
   if output_file:
       savefig(fig, 'myplot.png')```
Would the equivalent in julia be:
```function plot(X::Vector{Int}, output_file::Union{Nothing, String}=Nothing):
   ...
   if output_file != Nothing
       savefig(fig, output_file)
   end
end```

text:
Ah, gotcha. If you’re in a high-level function and you have a ton of options that a user may or may not want to set then yeah I think there’s nothing wrong with doing it with an if-statement just like that.

The other option like you mentioned above would be to dispatch to a different function, which I’d do more if this were a low-level function that other functions will call, especially if any of the options changes the return type of the function.

text: Oh and just as an extra thing there shouldn’t be any performance penalty AFAIU for just leaving off the type signature of the kwarg — though sometimes it is useful for readability/documentation. There’s an interesting tradeoff in function type signatures, as in the “Over-constraining argument types” section of  <https://www.oxinabox.net/2020/04/19/Julia-Antipatterns.html>
